title: Evolução dos caracteres intracranianos de Folivora (Pilosa, Xenarthra) através de análises tridimensionais
authors: Azevedo, Sergio Alex Kugland de, orient.
Universidade Federal do Rio de Janeiro.
abstract: Esta tese apresenta quatro manuscritos cujos foco é a paleoneurologia de preguiças pleistocênicas. A paleoneurologia estuda as estruturas do endocrânio de vertebrados extintos, buscando através destas características entender a evolução e até mesmo a paleobiologia destes táxons. Os Folivora são um clado pertencente a super ordem Xenarthra e atualmente são representados por apenas dois gêneros, com hábitos muito restritos. Entretanto seu registro fossilífero é rico, com variadas famílias e distribuição geográfica. Para entender as mudanças ocorridas nos hábitos destes animais, foram feitos quatro estudos usando a paleoneurologia das espécies Valgipes bucklandi, Eremotherium laurillardi e Nothrotherium maquinense. Os crânios passaram por tomografia computadorizada de alta resolução e as imagens geradas foram analisadas e editadas para reconstrução tridimensional das estruturas endocranianas. No primeiro estudo foram analisadas e descritas as características gerais do encéfalo, nervos e seios cranianos. As análises sugeriram um forte componente filogenético, agrupando alguns clados conforme a proposta vigente, mas também respostas aos hábitos dos táxons. Possivelmente Valgipes bucklandi teria um bom uso de capacidades olfativas. Juntamente com Nothrotherium maquinense, também mostra que provavelmente teriam boa acuidade sensorial na maxila, através de estruturas como vibrissas. Eremotherium laurillardi mostrou o nervo craniano hipoglosso bastante espesso, o que concorda com a ideia debatida na literatura, a respeito de bom controle e protrusão da língua. Também foi feita uma análise através de morfometria geométrica, que também demonstrou o componente filogenético na morfologia encefálica. Entretanto os hábitos também mostraram interferência nesta variação, posicionando sempre animais que poderiam subir em árvores, sempre próximos nos gráficos.As análises demonstraram que os bulbos olfatórios parecem ser responsáveis pela maior variação no encéfalo, seguido pelo cerebelo e a posição da fissura rinal. O terceiro manuscrito reconstruiu a orelha interna de Valgipes bucklandi, Eremotherium laurillardi e Glossotherium robustum. Observou-se na comparação da estrutura de outros Folivora descritas na literatura que a orelha interna de G. robustum pode apresentar variação intraespecífica. Tanto morfologicamente quanto a partir de cálculos de agilidades com base metodológica na literatura, os animais seriam lentos, porém mais ágeis que as preguiças atuais. Dentre estes V. bucklandi obteve maior índice de agilidade. Durante as análises paleoneurológicas, foi observada uma anomalia em um dos exemplares de Valgipes bucklandi, um alargamento na região da sella túrcica, que não estava presente nos outros dois exemplares da mesma espécie. Foram descartadas questões tafonômicas e observados sinais de remodelamento. Foram descartadas síndromes que causariam alterações ósseas, uma vez que o crânio se apresentava com proporções normais. A alteração foi atribuída a uma paleopatologia de tecido mole, provável adenoma hipofisário benigno de crescimento lento que causaria o remodelamento ósseo observado, criando novo assoalho ósseo na base do basisfenóde. Este trabalho foi incluído na tese por apresentar outra possibilidade da paleoneurologia, como reportar paleopatologia no encéfalo de organismos extintos, o que não seria descoberto de outra maneira.

Abstract of thesis submitted to the Programa de Pós-graduação em Ciências Bio- lógicas (Zoologia), Museu Nacional, Universidade Federal do Rio de Janeiro - UFRJ, as part of the necessary requisites to the obtainment of the title of doctoral degree in Zoology.

This thesis presents four manuscripts whose f ocus is the paleoneurology of Pleistocene sloths. Paleoneurology studies the endocast structures of extinct vertebrae, seeking to un- derstand the evolution and even the paleobiology of these taxa. Folivora is a Xenarthra clade and has only two extant genera with very restricted habits. However, its fossiliferous record is rich, with varied families and geographic distribution. Here we developed four manuscripts using Paleoneurology methodology to understand the change of habits among these taxa. The skulls o f Valgipes bucklandi , Eremotherium laurillardi , and Nothrotherium maquinense underwent high -resolution computed tomography, and the images generated were analyzed and edited for three -dimensional reconstruction of the endo -cranial struc- tures.

In the first study, the general characteristics of the brain, nerves, and cranial sinuses were analyzed and described. The analyzes suggested a strong phylogenetic component, and groups clades according to the recently accepted phylogeny. Although it also responses to the habits of the taxa. Possibly Valgipes bucklandi would use olfactory abilities. Together with Nothrotherium maquinense , Valgipes also shows that they probably had good sensory acuity in the maxilla through vibrissae . Eremotherium laurillardi showed a ve ry thick hy- poglossal cranial nerve, which agrees with the idea discussed in the literature regarding best control and protrusion of the tongue. An analysis was also made using geometric mor- x

phometry, which also demonstrated the phylogenetic component in bra in morphology. However, habits also showed interference in this variation, placing climber animals close in the plotted graphs. The analyzes also showed olfactory bulbs as responsible for the vari- ation in the brain, followed by the cerebellum and the posit ion of the rhinal fissure. The third manuscript re -constructed the inner ear of Valgipes bucklandi , Eremotherium lau- rillardi , and Glossotherium robustum . Comparing the structure of other Folivora described in the literature, the inner ear of G. robustum may show intraspecific variation. Both mor- phologically and based on agility calculations based on methodologies in the literature point to these taxa as slow but more agile than current sloths. Among these V. bucklandi proved to be more agile. During paleone urological analysis, an anomaly has noticed an enlargement in the region of the sella turcica in one of the specimens of Valgipes buck- landi, which was not present in the other two specimens of the same species. Taphonomic issues were discarded and were obs erved osteophytes. Syndromes that would cause bone changes were ruled out since the skull was of normal proportions. The alteration was at- tributed to soft -tissue paleopathology, like a slow -growing, probably benign pituitary ade- noma that would cause bone r emodeling, creating a new bone floor at the basis of the ba- sisphenoid. This work was included in the thesis because it presents the possibilities of paleoneurology, how to report paleopathology in the brain of extinct organisms, which would not be discover ed otherwise.

A Subordem Folivora Delsuc, Catzeflis, Stanhope e Douzery, 2001, é composta dos animais conhecidos popularmente como preguiças, pertencentes a Superordem Xenarthra Cope, 1889. Atualmente os Folivora têm hábitos arbóreos e são representados por apenas duas famílias (Chiarello 2008), diferindo de seus representantes extintos. As preguiças terrestres apresentavam grande diversidade de famílias, ampla distribuição geográfica e diversos hábitos de vida, ocupan do variados nichos ecológicos (e.g. , Naples 1989; Bargo et As formas atuais perderam o hábito locomotor terrícola e seus membros estão adaptados para o comportamento trepador. De acordo com Jerison (1976) diferenças no desenvolvimento neurológ ico entre espécies vivas são notáveis, deste modo as mudanças comportamentais ocorridas no curso da evolução dos Folivora podem estar refletidas em alterações na morfologia intracraniana. Modificações conhecidas na caixa craniana, ligadas a evolução encefá lica, estão diretamente ligada s aos aspectos da fisiologia comportamental, o que envolve o controle das adaptações motoras além de aumento da acuidade sensorial (Jerison 1973). No encéfalo e strutura e função estão de alguma forma correlacionadas e, assim, moldes endocranianos podem permitir algumas inferências quanto às capacidades funcionais e comportamentais (Jerison 1973).

Outro modo de se observar a evolução das estruturas intracranianas do grupo estudado é através do uso de análises quantitativas, atr avés de metodologias como a Morfometria Geométrica. Esta é uma ferramenta que permite quantificar as mudanças nas formas e suas variações, através de um componente estatístico (Monteiro & Reis 1999). Seu uso em biomodelos tridimensionais permite capturar q uantitativamente a variação morfológica do endocrânio entre os táxons estudados. Uma primeira análise (Amaral et al. 2021), através da morfometria multivariada com medidas lineares básicas, com animais Xenarthra permitiu observar componentes principais (2 e 3) relacionados com estruturas encefálicas, atuando na evolução encefálica do grupo . A análise das diferenças entre os sistemas neuronais nos animais com hábitos distintos permite entender quais desses sistemas sofreram pressões seletivas (Arhens 2014).

A reconstrução digital de estruturas encefálicas, como orelha e seios intracranianos , tem grande relevância em inferência comportamental . Por exemplo , ao analisarmos a reconstrução da orelha interna de um animal extinto nos torna possível inferir quanto à s capacidades auditivas, equilíbrio e mesmo habilidades locomotoras destes animais (Bruns & Schmieszek 1980; Ketten 1997; Billet et al. 2013).

A paleoneurologia apresenta suas limitações, especialmente por estarmos tratando de estruturas que não existem fisicamente, mas apenas molde s do que as mesmas seriam. Entretanto este campo de pesquisa ainda é uma ferramenta importante para compreender a fisiologia do cérebro e estruturas sensoriais de animais do passado. Através de comparações com táxons pr óximos viventes , podemos aumentar o campo de inferência e buscar respostas a respeito de como, fisiologicamente, tais estruturas respondiam ao ambiente e hábitos, dando pistas a respeito da paleobiologia dos táxons do passado.
2 OBJETIVOS
2.1 Gerais:

Compreender como a mudança de hábitos dos Folivora, de terrícolas para arborícolas se espelha na variação das estruturas intracranianas e debater se tais mudanças na morfologia encefálica. Adicionalmente , através das informações obtidas pela morfologia destas estruturas, contribuir com informações a respeito dos hábitos destes animais.
2.2 Específicos:

• Descrever as estruturas intracranianas ainda não descritas (neurocrânio, nervos cranianos, orelha intern a e seios cranianos ) a partir dos modelos tridimensionais dos táxons selecionados para a Ordem Xenarthra. • Comparar com estruturas já descritas em táxons fósseis e atuais. • Usar a morfometria geométrica para observar os componentes responsáveis pela maior variação, das estru turas encefálicas do grupo e tecer considerações .
3.1 Relação com o tema geral da tese:

O primeiro artigo da tese descreve a paleoneurologia inédita de três espécies de preguiças pleistocênicas, Nothrotherium maquinense , Valgipes bucklandi e Eremotherium laurillardi , a partir da reconstrução digital das cavidades internas do crânio fossilizad o. O artigo tem como objetivo fazer um apanhado histórico a respeito dos estudos paleoneurológicos de preguiças terrícolas e traçar um comparativo, não só entre outras preguiças (extintas e atuais), quanto com outros Xenarthra. O artigo começa falando so bre a paleoneurologia, seu histórico e sua importância para o entendimento de como o encéfalo se desenvolveu entre os mamíferos. Na sua discussão são abordadas as similaridades das estruturas intracranianas entre os táxons cuja estruturas endocranianas já foram descritas.

Este artigo é determinante para o desenvolvimento da tese, uma vez que para poder desenvolver os trabalhos sobre a evolução das estruturas intracranianas torna -se necessário não somente a descrição de estruturas inéditas, mas também o ent endimento do papel que elas exerceram na vida destes animais. Deste modo, este primeiro artigo agrega parte do trabalho desenvolvido em dissertação, para que seja possível observar a paleoneurologia de Folivora de maneira completa.

3.2 ABSTRACT

Paleoneurology is the study of endocranial structures in extinct animals and can enlighten the evolution and habits of taxa through the recognition of correlated signals in the fossil record. Folivora is a group of animals represented by two extant genera with arboreal habits, but their extinct representatives exhibit a large range of genera and habits. This paper aims to understand this change. The skull of Valgipes bucklandi , Nothrotherium maquinense and Eremotherium laurillardi , were scanned, the endocranial structures were identified and digitally reconstructed. The general endocranial morphology of the specimen’s group s them as expected by the most recent phylogeny. Valgipes bucklandi and Nothrotherium maquinense present a single exit for a well -developed V 2 cranial nerve , which is related to good sensory acuity of the maxilla. The cranial nerve XII is thick in Eremothe rium , which is compatible with the ability to control and protrude the tongue , indicated in the literature. Except for N. maquinense , the specimens have extensive cranial pneumatization. Turbinates were observed in Valgipes bucklandi and Nothrotherium maqu inense , in which maxilloturbinates are more extensive. Probably, olfaction had some importance in Valgipes bucklandi life. The encephalization quotient ranged from 0.7 to 1.5, agreeing with the groove patterns on the development of the neocortex in Folivor a and with the rhinal fissure position, medially at brain height. In general, the analysis of Folivora brain suggests a strong phylogenetic component, but possibly some endocranial structures had morphology shaped by environment changes.

3.3 INTRODUCTION
3.3.1 PALEONEUROLOGY

Paleoneurology is the study of endocranial structures in extinct organisms (Butler & Hodos 2005). Beyond morphological descriptions, Paleoneurology can br ing new information about extinct animal habits, standing for the interface between more embracing areas: Paleontology and Neurology. Additionally, Paleoneurology encompasses an understanding of vertebrate brain evolution and the endocranial development when allowing identify brain evolution through correlated signs at the fossil record (Jerison1976; Buchholtz & Seyfarth, 2001; Witmer & Ridgely 2008; Witmer et al. 2008). The paleoneurological analysis also brings more information about behavio r and phylogeny, helping to understand how selective pressures change encephalic structure morphology (Jerison 1973). This research allows us the understanding about what information the brain is physiologically able to process, producing data about the se nsorial Paleobiology of extinct taxa (Witmer 1995a).

This field includes not only the investigation of the brain itself but all structures in the so -called “endocast” or endocranium , the internal cast of morphological structures in the vertebrate skull. T his study also allows identifying morphological traits of encephalic evolution through correlated signs at the fossil record (Jerison 1976). However, understand the Paleobiology of extinct organisms, especially towards behavioral inference, is a complex task. Obtainable data through paleontological techniques are limited, such as fossil itself, aside taphonomic aspects. Rodrigues (2011) indicat es that there is a difference between understanding what an animal could physically achieve (e. g. digging capacity and ability to climb trees) and what it actually could do. Paleoneurology does not directly answer the question , but provides an understandi ng of what physiologically the endocranium would be able to process, bringing data on the sensory Paleobiology of extinct taxa (Witmer, 1995).

One of the first studies in the Paleoneurology field was from Marsh (1874), through a brief communication about t he size of tertiary (Neogene) mammal brains (Faria 2018). Noticing the increase of the brain represented by natural endocranial casts of extinct mammals, Mar sh (1874) postulates the “General Laws of Brain Growth” based it on a tendency toward a progressive growth of the brain, linking size to the complexity of mammals’ brains in the course of evolution. Marsh (1877) believed that all Neogene

mammals had relatively small brains, and in that geologic period, there was a gradual increase in brain size, limited to the cerebral hemispheres, and, in some taxa, brains circumvolutions become more complex. The author believed that the brain growth in these animals would be the key to understand evolutionary changes . The struggle to survive act as selective pressure, since mammals with bigger brains prevailed, and structures consider as plesiomorphic by Marsh (cerebellum, olfactory bulbs) decreased. Similarly, Marsh defended the idea that taxa doomed to extinction would have smaller brains than average Georges Cuvier (1769 -1832) analyzed a fossilized brain of an Anoplotherium and observ ed its absence of circumvolutions and concluded that the endocast present , what he called , “the real form” of the brain. Th e lissencephalic aspect of that endocast provided support to Marsh ’s law for believing that the Neogene animal has lower intelligence grade (Jerison 1973; Faria 2018).

Paleoneurology as a field of study also advances based on observations of Osborn (1857 -1935) regarding size, growth, and structures of vertebrate brain morphology. Osborn (1906 ; 1910) used brain size as a taxonomic diagnosis and applied Marsh’s law, indicating that declining taxa indeed have smaller brains, despite point out that it would not b e the only cause of Cenozoic extinctions (Osborn 1921; Faria 2018).

Even with reservations, Marsh’s “General Laws of Brain Growth” guided paleoneurological studies for some decades until the rise of modern Paleoneurology through Tilly Edinger’s (1897 -1967) research. Considered the founder of Paleoneurology, Tilly promoted comparative neuroanatomy associated with stratigraphic studies and was the first to investigate, compare and organize fossil endocranial molds data, both in Europe and North America. Eding er brought advances in Paleoneurology and was responsible for refuted Marshal’s Law (Buchholtz & Seyfarth 2001; Faria 2018).

After Edinger, Paleoneurology gains importance through the quantitative methods used by Henry Jerison . Jerison, in 1955 , relates brain evolution with the evolution of intelligence and works on the issue through a quantitative bias , later call ed Encephalization Quotient (EQ). The EQ is a measure of relative size. It allows the comparison of different species' brain size, bas ed on the ratio between expected brain size for a taxon’s body mass and its observed brain volume. (Buchholtz & Seyfarth 2001; Carvalho 2007; Faria 2018). Jerison (1955; 1973; 1985) . Jerison (1985) approaches encephalization as animal intelligence, an exte nsion of the idea that cognitive domain activities increase brain size

and bring information such as body increase factor and its interference in the evolutionary process. This type of approach leads Jerison to formulate the proper -mass principle, a concep t that claims that the brain’s processing capacity is designated in distinct functions proportionally to the importance of these structures in the species lives. For instance, species that depend more on auditory information present an expansion of the aud itory cortex (Jerison 1973; 1991). Jerison’s quantitative methodology had a great acceptance and is still widely used to aid the understanding of evolutionary processes and, with Edinger’s comparative neuroanatomy, improving knowledge about endocranial fun ctionality issues and its connection with behavior and ecology of various taxa (Walsh & Knoll 2011; Faria, Besides behavior and ecology, Paleoneurology was used to provide characters to phylogenetic data. Radinsky (1971; 1973; 1975) researched brain sulci patterns in carnivores and used as characters for systematic analysis about carnivores. These patterns were also used in carnivores’ systematic reviews by other authors (e.g., Lyras & Van Der Geer 2003; Lyras et al. 2006). Radinsky (1976 ; 1977 ; 1982 ) also proven that primitive carnivore brains are not larger than extant ones. Finarelli & Flynn (2009) used robust phylogenies as hypothesis tests about the brain size and behavior.

After Jerison’s progress and the popularization of non -invasive radiologi cal techniques, paleoneurology research expanded . From the 2000s, CT scans became popular in paleoneurological studies, together with three -dimensional reconstruction techniques. This kind of approach in extinct vertebrates made possible more paleobiology inferences (Walsh & Knoll 2011). Rogers (2005) use the methodology to describe an Allosaurus brain and made inferences based on comparisons with extant animals. Witmer & Ridgely (2008b) deepened the olfactory abilities of Tyrannosaurus rex. Macrini et al. (2006) described the brain of extinct monotremes; Macrini et al. (2007a;b) conducted a series of studies on endocranium, habits, the phylogeny of different animals; Silcox et al. (2009) described the brain of a small extinct primate; Rodrigues (2011) desc ribe and commented on the evolution of cynodonts endocranium; Dozo & Martinez (2016) describe d Rhynchippus equinus brain. The “Museu Nacional da Universidade Federal do Rio de Janeiro ” (MN/UFRJ) also developed several types of research with CT scan technol ogy and reunited them in two books (Lopes et al. 2013; 2019).
Over the decades, there have been occasional publications addressing Xenarthra paleoneurology. Gervais (1869) interpreted and made brief descriptions of natural brain

molds from Scelidotherium, Mylodon, Megatherium, Glyptodon, Eutatu . Jakob (1912) described natural molds from Xenarthra. Dechaseaux (1958; 1962a;b; 1971) revised the group's register of endocranial molds, with brief descriptions of new materials. Elliot - Smith's (1898) study on Xenar thra's brain also described a fossilized endocast patterns of fossil representatives and proposed a neurological evolutionary model for the group. He proposed implications of Paleoneurology in the phylogenetic systematics of Xenarthra. Dozo (1987, 1994) de scribed endocranial molds of Hapalops indifferens and Eucholoeops fronto .

However, contemporaneous research focusing on Xenarthra paleoneurology is not usual despite the rich possibility of solid comparison with extant taxa. Recently, Tambusso & Fariña (20 15a;b) focused on Cingulata and Boscani et al. (2020a;b) study comparatively the paleoneurology of an Argentine Glossotherium robustum and a Catonyx tarijensis . The increase of studies focused on Xenarthra contribute to complete the data on the brain evolution of the taxon and has a great relevance on the paleoneurological research.
3.3.2. FOLIVORA

Extant Folivora is represented by the genres Bradypus Linnaeus, 1758 (three -toed sloths) and Choloep us Linnaeus, 1758 (two -toed sloths). Oppositely, the extinct Folivora representatives, ground -sloths, show a great diversity of families' wide geographical distribution and diverse life habits, occupying several ecological niches (e.g., Naples 1989; Bargo et al. 2006). The fossil record shows this diversity and the distribution, with remnants found in the Americas (North, Central, South). Ground sloths could achieve great sizes, reaching over 6 tons, as the megatheriid Eremotherium laurillardi (Dantas et al. 2019 ; McDonald 2005). Based on knowledge about extant Xenarthra, it was supposed that the extinct representatives also had low metabolism, so its large body size suggested that these animals were quadrupedal and slow. However, several studies show vari able life habits (McDonald & De Iuliis 2008; Pujos et al. 2012).

The evolution of the brain is linked to known changes in the skull and aspects of behavioral physiology, involving the control of motor adaptations and the increase in sensory acuity, causin g structure and function to be correlated (Jerison 1973). Thus, it is not wrong to conclude that behavioral changes that occurred during the evolution of Folivora may have led to changes in intracranial morphology. So, th is contribution aims to
draw a para llel between previous works and describe the paleoneurology of three species of Pleistocene ground sloths and compare them to extant Xenarthra.

3.4 MATERIAL AND METHODS

We submitted to CT scan the skulls of extant and fossil Xenarthra (supplement ary data 1 for specifications ). Fossil specimens are two skulls of Eremotherium laurillardi Lund, 1842 (MN 2225 -V and MN 422 -V) and a Glossotherium robustum Owen, 1940 (MN 3944 -V) of the Paleovertebrate Collection from MN/UFRJ (see above for institutional abbreviations); three fossil skulls of Valgipes bucklandi Lund, 1839 (MCT 4271 -M, MCT 4272 -M e MCT 3993 -M) and a Nothrotherium maquinense Lund, 1839 (MCT 4229 -M), from CPRM (Fig. 1 ). Since we already take all CT scans previously, the 2018 fire at Museu Nacional UFRJ did not directly affect this work. Also, of the fossil material, only MN 3944 -V, the Glossotherium robustum , was damaged, but although the fire not destroyed completely, it was harmed .

Concerning towards the extant specimens: Bradypus tridactylus Linnaeus, 1758 (MN 3047), Bradypus variegatus Schinz, 1825 (MN 7609), Bradypus torquatus Linnaeus, 1758 (MN 10981), Choloepus hoffmanni Peters,1858 (MN 7577) , Tolypeutes tricin ctus Linnaeus, 19758 (MN 23992), Tamandua tetradactyla Linnaeus, 1758 (MN 23953) . All of them are from the Museu Nacional UFRJ’s Mastozoology collection.

Tomographic slices were obtained in the coronal, sagittal and axial anatomical planes, which allow the superposition of one slice on the next. The sections are converted into images in DICOM format (Digital Imaging and Communications in Medicine), which makes manipulation possible in DICOM image editing software. Image analysis enables the identification o f endocranial structures and their manual editing in each section in the anatomical planes on a digitizing table using various image and volume rendering software. After editing, the programs generate a three -dimensional model that allows observation in di fferent views, the measurement of structures, as well as obtaining the
volume referring to each outlined structure. The segmentation is based on grayscale values and reflect the density and composition of the specimen.

Then the intracranial structures were identified, described, and compared. The image segmentation process was performed by a volume rendering software, Materialise Mimics 10.01 (at that point, from INT) digital tools.

The software allows to take linear measurement of the endocast structures and their volume s. Thus, it was possible to apply the encephalization quotient (EQ) equation, which compares the animal body mass with the endocranial volume, given its expected relative brain size. It is the ratio of the encephalon's actual size against the body mass and estimated by the allometric function for the brain through a regression line of brain volume ratio and body mass in grams with a constant exponential. Jerison (1973) determined an exponential for mammals (0.12M0.67), Tambusso & Fa riña (2015a) seeking to adapt the exponential to the metabolism of Xenarthra reach the exponential 0.606 (0.12M0.606) where M is the body mass in grams. The encephalic volume includes olfactory bulbs and the cerebellum, assuming that the encephalic tissue has a similar density as liquid water, with a specific gravity of 1g/cm3 (Jerison 1973; Macrini 2007a; Silcox et al. 2010; Dozo & Martinez 2016). For mammals, Jerison (1973) alleged that any brain measurement, which includes weight, has an inherent error o f a minimum order of 5 to 10% since encephalon size decreases when dissected and also because the definition of weight is vague. Macrini et al. (2007a) argument that, in vivo, the pressure of cerebrospinal fluids causes the brain volume to be higher than t he values obtained in preserved specimens, for example. However, the mammal brain fills the inner skull, making impressions on the internal cranial surface (Macrini et al. 2007a; Jerison 1973). Since we did not use dissected brains in this study, only valu es related to the impressions in the endocast, we assume the obtained values are close to reality. The values obtained from the three -dimensional cast of the brain (the present study) are similar to the ones obtained through dissection (Ferreira et al. 2005) for extant sloths Bradypus variegatus e B. trydactilus .

To obtain the encephalic quotient, it is also necessary to estimate the body mass of the analyzed specimens. For this was used Fariña et al. (1998), based on Janis (1990) methodology, adapted troug h allometric equations, and by the mean of the masses indicated for each of the measures to minimize the error in the mass estimate. Since we only had access to the skulls of the Folivora specimens, as many measures as possible were used for each animal. Still, as pointed out by Fariña et al. (1998), cranial
measures tend to underestimate body mass for large animals, which implied the use of means obtained in the literature for the same species animals.

Related to the nomenclature used to describe endocranial structures, we follow Macrini et al. (2007) and Boscaini et al. (2020a;b). For turbinates there are basically three sets of structures: N asoturbinates, Ethmoturbinates and Maxilloturbinates. The nomenclature and its divisions change according to the authors, who often divide them according to the proximity of the skull bones , or even called nasal conchae (e.g., Favoretto et al. 2013, Pitana et al. 2013). In this work, we will follow the one used by Hillenius (1992) without the ethmoturbinates divisions.

3.5.1 Systematic Paleontology:

Valgipes bucklandi (MCT 4272 -M, MCT 4271 -M, MCT 3993 -M) Family Mylodontidae Ameghino, 1889 Subfamily Scelidotheriinae Ameghino, 1904 Genus Valgipes Gervais, 1874 Valgipes bucklandi Lund, 1839 Locality:

MCT 4272 -M, MCT 4271 -M: Lapa dos Peixes, Serra do Ramalho plateau, southwestern Bahia MCT 3993 -M: Gruna das Três Cobras, Serra do Ramalho plateau, southwestern Bahia Digital Endocast Three Valgipes bucklandi skulls were submitted to a tomographic scan. All the specimens are well preserved, allowing the observation of the endocranial structures . Due to taphonomic conditions, the third specimen of Valgipes bucklandi (MCT 4271 -M), has its inner skull fully fille d by sediment, resulting in poor digital reconstruction. The frontal lobes present a slight depression in the most cranial part, anterior to the circular fissure. The brain hemispheres have a general oval conformation of the parietal lobes. The t emporal lobes are slightly expanded, with a visible longitudinal fissure, which divides brain hemispheres. The rhinal fissure is emphasized, causing the pyriform lobes to

become highlighted. The rostral part of the rhinal fissure is ventral to the pyriform lobe. The caudal portion of the rhinal fissure is positioned about the medial point of the brain height marking a division between the pyriform and temporal lobes and displays a ventrally oriented inclination (Fig. 2A-B).

Ventrally it is visible the pitu itary fossa, wide and convex, caudally concerning optic chiasma. In the specimen MCT 3993 -M, the pituitary fossa ( sella turcica ) is wider, demarcating a large, rounded ventral projection, measuring 15,33 mm length, 17,91 mm width, and 15,96 mm height (meas urements for all the specimens in supplementary data 2) . Although the lissencephaly general aspect, we can notice grooves that can be interpreted as sulci (Fig. 2A). In frontal lobe we can see most anteriorly position the presylvian sulci and postero -laterally, the presylvian sulci. At the parietal lobe, in lateral posterior position, we can see the suprasylvian sulcus.

Although the brain hemispheres do not overlap the cerebellum, it presents a separation between the brain and the cerebellum by a Cerebellar Ossified Tentorium, which stretches across the cerebellum width and hides the transverse fissure and the cerebellar vermis. Laterally we can see the paraflocullum (Fig. 2B).

At the rostral extremity is the olfactory bulbs, which are pedunculate. The olfac tory bulbs are slightly rectangular, flattened dorso -ventrally, extended at the front edge, with the rostral ends forming a medial -lateral diagonal. Following the olfactory peduncle in the ventral view, we observed the olfactory tract that presents a cylin drical shape (Fig. 2B). The observable endocranial structures in the three Valgipes specimens are similar as expected, except for the enlargement in the pituitary fossa in MCT 3993 -M, probably a result of taphonomic alterations or by paleopathology .

Cranial Nerves Bustamante (2017) previously analyzed the skulls of these specimens, so it is not the objective of the work to rewrite but to point out some characteristics of the neurocranium only. The neurocranium of all Valgipes bucklandi specimens in this study are similar. Dorsally the parasagittal ridges are delimited by the nuchal crest and by the postorbital process of the frontal. The parasagittal ridge follows the postorbital process and passes through the parietal, and proceeds to the squamosal. The wedge -shaped parasagittal ridges narrow and make a more pronounced curve in the most posterior part of the parietal bone before going to the squamosal bone in the specimens MCT 4271 -M and MCT 4272 -

M. In MCT 3993 -M, the ridges are further apart. There is also a process that could be a crest in the midline of the parietal. The ventral part of the neurocranium is visualized in the MCT 3993 -M specimen .

It is possible to observe the emergence of the cranial nerves in the endocranium and its ex it through the cranial foramina (Fig. 3). The foramina of these specimens were listed and described by Bustamante (2017), so the focus is only on those related to cranial nerves. In Valgipes bucklandi , the orbital fissure shares the same opening with the r otundum foramen, and this opening is confluent with the optical canal. The optic nerve (II) emerges more anteriorly from the skull and extends through the optic foramen, converging with the orbit -rotundum foramen ( named by Cartelle et al. 2009), however internally ha s a separate opening for the optic canal. Finally, the cranial nerve II will find exit through the sphenorbital fissure, along with cranial nerves IV, V 1, V2, and IV.

The mandibular nerve (V 3) exits through the foramen ovale, which op ens externally on the posterior surface of the pterygoid bone, at the level of the anterior surface of the glenoid fossa. The cranial nerves VII and VIII (facial and vestibulocochlear respectively) emerge through the internal acoustic meatus, and the nerve s are very subtle and thin. Laterally to the pons, the emergence of the glossopharyngeal, vagus and accessory nerves (respectively IX, X and XI) are visible through the jugular foramen, a rounded and wide fossa, latero -anteriorly limited by the entotympani c bone, latero -posteriorly by the parocondylar process of the exoccipital bone.

In V. bucklandi , the jugular foramen is larger than the hypoglossal foramen, which gives opening to the hypoglossal nerve. The specimen MCT 3993 -M presents two external openings for this foramen in both sides, and just one internally. The specimens MCT 4271 - M and MCT 4272 -M do not have this characteristic .

Cranial sinuses and turbinates Of the three specimens of Valgipes bucklandi examined by CT scan, only one ha s a large amount of sediment, making it difficult to see the cranial sinuses, but MCT 3993 -M is the one that best allows the observation of all structures.

The MCT 3993 -M skull is highly pneumatized in the most anterior (rostral) part of the skull. The tur binates are visible, not in the details of the bones (which are very thin and are therefore easily lost in fossilization), but visible through distinctive impressions in the sediments, observable in tomographic images (Fig. 4 A-C).

The cranial sinuses are enclosed in the frontal, extending from the most anterior edge to the limit with the most anterior portion of the parietal bone, dorsally to the brain cavity. The extensive frontal sinus is dividing by non -symmetrical septa (Fig. 4 D) and in its posterior view merges with alisphenoid and orbitosphenoid sinuses, latero -ventrally with squamosal sinus. Also, through the ventral view it is possible to see two small irregular sinuses with a postero -anterior direction in the basisphenoid bone (Fig 4 E). The maxillary sinuses extend from the anterior portion of the maxilla to the lacrimal canal and like the frontal sinuses, also exhibit an asymmetrical division. Located medially to the maxillary sinus are the maxilloturbinates, which Bustamante (2017), in her dissertation, highlighted the wavy characteristic in this specie. The Maxilloturbinates are positioned on the anterior part of the skull at the level of the fourth molar (M4), from the nasal cavity to the palatal process. They project dorsally in a single gyrus (descript ed by Bustamante 2017) contacting the nasal surface of the maxilla at its most anterior point. They are irregular and more extensive in anteroposterior length than nasoturbinates.

The nasal cavity consists of two openings, separated by the perpendicular lamina of the ethmoid, is well developed and extends to the body of the pre -sphenoid bone, which represents just over half the anteroposterior length of the skull. The openings of the nasal cavity are regularly wide and slightly cylindric al, following the entrance of the snout, from the break, and taper as they approach the nasal region, following up to the olfactory area, in front of the olfactory bulbs.

The anterior region to the olfactory bulbs is highly vascularized, showing nasoturbin ates (=ethmoturbinates I = dorsal conchae) and laterally to it the ethmoturbinates (= ectoturbinates = medial conchae), difficult to be digitally reconstructed due to the delicate and thin structure of multiple curved channels that are best seen in tomogra phic images (Fig. 4 A-C). These nasoturbinates extend into the nasal cavity and gradually become wider, ending narrower near the nasopharyngeal meatus.

Relative Brain Size We used to estimate Valgipes bucklandi body mass from the skulls, Fariña et al. (1998), based on Janis (1990). However, to calculate the body mass from the skull tends to underestimate weight for big animals, such as V. bucklandi . In their study. Fariña et al.

(1998) verify body mass estimates for a Scelidotherium , and realize a values discrepancy, using femur circumference measures, the sloth specimen presented 3153 kg, but using total length of the skull measurements, they came to a 642 kg weight. For V. buckl andi we used multiple measurements of the skull (Occipital height; Basicranial length; Paraoccipital Process length; Posterior Skull length; Palatal width, Muzzle width; Suborbital depth; Skull Total length), and came to the mean 316 kg weight for MCT 3993 -M, and 332 kg weight for MCT 4272 -M. However, Dantas et al. (2017), collected a Valgipes Bucklandi specimen in Rio Grande do Norte and, using mass estimates based on femur measures, reached an estimate of 980 kg weight. De Oliveira & Santos (2018) also es timate body mass of a Valgipes bucklandi and came a result of 1591 kg weight. Since there is a significant difference between these results, we used the average of all these mass values (Table 1) and came to 0.7 as an encephalization quotient result.

3.5.2 Systematic Paleontology: Nothrotherium maquinense (MCT 4229 -M) Xenarthra (Cope, 1889) Pilosa (Flower, 1883) Nothrotheriidae Ameghino, 1920 Nothrotherium Lydekker, 1889 Nothrotherium maquinense Lund, 1839 Specimen: MCT 4229 -M Locality : Lapa dos Peixes cave, Serra do Ramalho plateau, southwestern Bahia

Digital Endocast The digital endocast of Nothrotherium maquinense , MCT 4229 -M (Fig. 5), fills the entire cranial vault, given an estimative of 7,7 cm width and 9,8 cm length (supp. data 2). Dorsally , the neocortex is cordiform, the temporal lobes are larger medial -laterally, due to the round pyriform lobes emphasized by the dorsal position of the well -demarcated rhinal fissure. In the frontal lobe, we see a slight dorsoventral depression at the most anterior extremity.

There are some grooves (Fig. 5 A-B) at the endocast we can interpret as sulci, although the taphonomic issues, as the great amount of sediment, do not allow a clean tridimensional reconstruction of the endocast. However, at the frontal lobe some marks can be interpreted as the presylvian sulcus and at the most anterior position, the presylvian gyri, postero -medially to it, the lateral sulcus.

The parietal lobes show a square conformation related to the encephalon . The parietal lobes present some groves lateral -medially that we can interpret as sulci sylvian (=pseudosylvian – Lyras 2009), suprasylvian and lateral, respectively. Between suprasylvian and lateral sulci, we see the suprasylvian gyrus.

The temporal lob es are pronounced and wide latero -anteriorly. The pyriform lobes are emphasized strongly by the rhinal fissure. The rostral part of the rhinal fissure is positioned more ventrally related to endocranium height, with a slight dorsal inclination, but the cau dal portion of the rhinal fissure is medially related to the endocranium height, dorsally to the pyriform lobe.

The occipital lobes have a slight depression with a transverse fissure, anterior to the cerebellum, well emphasized. The brain hemispheres do n ot overlap the cerebellum. In a general view, the morphology of this “small” Pleistocene sloth endocast presents a convex cerebellum, measuring 5 cm width and 4 cm length, but it was not possible to see it in detail. The skull was full of sediment, obscuri ng the tomographic images. So, we do not know if its cerebellum would be less complex it is not even possible to see the cerebellar vermis (Fig. 5), although, when related to the general size of the brain, the cerebellum seems large. Laterally it is possib le to see the flocculonodular lobe and the paraflocculus The olfactory bulbs are short, close to the brain, without peduncle, with a slight lateral projection. The left and right bulbs have a separation of a 76,31o angle. The olfactory tract is quite thick with a cylindrical form. In its ventral view, below the olfactory tract, is visible the optic chiasma. Caudally to the optic chiasma, the pituitary fossa ( sella turcica ) is visible as a convex and rounded reconstructed structure. The sella tur cica, depression that houses the pituitary gland, is round with a slight convexity.

Cranial Nerves The neurocranium of MCT 4229 -M its only available to see in lateral -dorsal view, the ventral part of the neurocranium is filled with sediment making it impossible to observe some structures as foramina and some of the cranial nerves, even per CT scan. Dorsally the neurocranium follows the general aspect of the brain, globose, and has mild dorsal -posterior depression, as mentioned by Cartelle & Fonseca (19 82). The sagittal crest is distinguishable by a weak suture between the parietals. In dorsal view, it also can be seen, at the posterior part of the skull, the occipital bone, and the occipital crest slightly accentuated, and bellow to it, the foramen magn um filled with sediment. The occipital condyles were not available for observation.

Although it is not possible to visualize the exit foramen due to the amount of sediment, it was possible to identify and reconstruct, even partially, the cranial nerves (Fig. 6), in both ventral and lateral views, according to the foramina and fissures that are internally observable. Still, in a ventral view of the 3D reconstruction, we can see the olfactory tract, which is cylindrical and thick. Below the olfactory tract, w e can see the optic chiasm and anteriorly to it, the canal for the optic nerve (II).

Laterally , the grove of the sphenorbital fissure is observed, it is confluent with the optic canal, and gives exit to the cranial nerves II, III, IV, V 1 and VI. Immediatel y posterior to this group of nerves, it is observed the emergence of the nerve V 2, corresponding to the foramen rotundum, showing a similarity towards the emergence of Bradypus cranial nerves (Boscaini et al. 2020a), since in Choloepus , Glossotherium and Catonyx (Boscaini et al. 2020a;b) the impress of the rotund foramen is not observed, marking an emergence of a cranial nerve separated from the sphenorbital fissure. Following the same line, posteriorly and directed lateral -anteriorly, the foramen ovale is observed corresponding to the emergence of the V 3 cranial nerve. It is curious that the maxillary and mandibular division (V 2 and V 3) of the trigeminal nerve are very well developed in Nothrotherium maquinense .

Lateral -posteriorly to the sella turcica is the emergence of the cranial nerves VII and VIII in the groove of the internal acoustic meatus. The vestibulocochlear nerve (VIII) follows to the inner ear. Subsequently, at the pons direction, a subtle groove corresponds to a subtle jugu lar foramen and the exit of the IX, X, and XI cranial nerves.

At last, the hypoglossal nerve, XII, the most posterior nerve, emerging from the skull through the hypoglossal foramen, in Nothtrotherium maquinense , as in the extant sloths, is not well -develo ped.

Cranial sinuses and turbinates The MCT 4229 -M has an exceptionally large amount of sediment. The nasal cavity and a large nasal opening can be seen between the sinuses (Fig. 7). The CT scan also shows what would be turbinates, with a variety of tortuous (oblique) small channels, lateral to the nasal cavity, and close to the more anterior extreme of the olfactory bulbs. As previously mentioned, the skull is well -preserved. The difficulty in analyzing some aspects is due to the amount of sediment that the preparation was unable to remove. Thus, we can observe the olfactory region well (Fig. 7 A-D). The nasoturbinate and the maxilloturbinates are observable better in tomographic images than in reconstructions (Fig. 7 A-C), due to the sediment interference in some cuts.

In the MCT 4229 -M specimen, th e nasoturbinates are well defined, narrow, following the entire snout to the olfactory bulbs in the nasal region. The structure is centrally located in the nasal cavity and has a more elongated and straighter medial portion, following the septum and extend ing dorsally to the most anterior part of the nasal bone. Subsequently, they reach the position of the postorbital bone, ending at the olfactory bulbs.

In the nasal cavity, the nasoturbinates are between the maxilloturbinates (axial view). Thus, the later al portions of the nasoturbinates are shorter and more spread mediolaterally and end up encompassing with the maxilloturbinates that fill the maxilla dorsal -ventrally on both sides.

The maxilloturbinates follow lateral and anterior the nasal, located later ally to the nasoturbinates and anteriorly to the ethmoturbinates. They are asymmetrical and wider than nasoturbinates. Turbinates are delicate nasal cavity bony structures and not usually preserve in the fossil record. However, the spaces between these str uctures were filled by sediment, allowing some observations . The ethmoturbinates a re posterior to the maxilloturbinates and follow ventrally the nasoturbinates. They are also quite asymmetrical, tangled, and strongly filled in an olfactory recess, with pos terior -anterior and dorsoventral projections (Fig. 7 A-B). In the 3D mask, the complete filling of the
structure is observable, but its labyrinth -like morphology can be seen only in the CT scan image (Fig. 7 B).

In the posterior part of the skull, it was n ot possible to observe cranial sinuses, as if, the brain occupies almost entirely the posterior part of the skull, ventrodorsally expanded. The better observable sinus is the frontal sinus, anteroposteriorly shorten and enclosed in the frontal bone (Fig. 7 D).

Relative Brain Size The body mass estimate ( Table 1) of N. maquinense is congruent with the estimative suggested in Cartelle (2000), which shows about 50 kg for average Nothrotherium maquinense. We came to a weight estimative of 62,8 kg. However, Dantas et al. (2019) estimate the two Nothrotherium maquinense body mass and find 134 and 192 kg. Considering that the authors estimate the masses by the femur, there may be an overestimation of this value (Fariña 1998), as these are higher values than those already indicated for this species in the literature (Cartelle 2000 ; De Oliveira & Santos 2018) and the one calculated here. To resolve the issue, we will use the approximate average of these values, 114,7 kg.

The endocast volume was 205 ml, us ing the equation based on Tambusso & Fariña (2015a) regressions for Xenarthra we came to a value of Encephalization Quotient ( Table 1) of 1,4 for Nothrotherium maquinense .

In addition to sagittal crests elevated, long, and bifurcated in its posterior third of the cranium. The MN 422 -V skull was sagittally divided, and just one -half of it available for CT sca n. However, it was possible to make observations from the three -dimensional model created by mirroring the parts. This skull probably belongs to a female specimen whose sagittal crest is shallow and not bifurcated, with the posterior region of the cranium further vertical. The parietal bone is shorter anteroposteriorly with a suture to the frontal visible and presents sagittal crests quite distinguished in MN 2225 -V. The nuchal crest exhibits large wrinkles that mark the cervical muscle insertions on the p osterior face of the occipital bone, this one has a rostral inclination, and the large occipital condyles are quite visible laterally, being located dorsally in relation to the tooth row (Gaudin 2004: 188 -1). The emergence of cranial nerves in both specimens, in lateral and ventral view, is quite visible.
